subject: RE: [junit] Ordered execution of test cases
msgSnippet: Boris, Don t fight the tool.  To JUnit, tests are independent, clean up after themselves, and can be run in any order.  If your tests are dependent on certain
messageBody:
Boris,

Don't fight the tool. To JUnit, tests are independent, clean up after
themselves, and can be run in any order. If your tests are dependent
on certain other tests being run before them, then you need to package
them into a single test.

It sounds like you can't run the later ones if the earlier ones fail,
anyway. I'd but them all in a method named testSomething and use the
String parameter to the assert() call to tell you which test failed
and why.

If you really want them to be independent, use the setUp and tearDown
methods to provide the necessary environment.

- George

-----Original Message-----
From: Boris Boehlen [mailto:boris@...-aachen.de]
[snip]
> Simply rename your test methods so they don't start with *test* word, this
> will prevent them to be executed by TestRunner.

This is a possible solution I found too. IMHO this is not very useful in
my case, because I still like to know which tests succeeded and which
didn't.
Unfortunately this does only work if you have written "testXXX" methods
because
JUnit invokes these methods independantly.

> Dependent actions should be written within one test case. There was
> a discussion on this mailing list few weeks ago (look for the thread
[junit]
> Order of Tests).
I found these discussions and do not agree. In my application area the
result is that I have several mini test case which depend heavily on
each other. The glue between them would be a number of test cases which
must themselves be used in larger test suites (can I nest test suites,
btw?).

Regards
Boris Boehlen
